Thomas Marsland offered me an opportunity to provide an early review of his new book, link below! My Amazon feedback; I'm including it here, as I was more than pleased with how he took such a joyless topic and breathed life into it. "I am not one to blow smoke and told him I'd give genuine feedback... Tom takes a topic as dry as the desert & and gives it life as lush as an oasis. Ok, that might be over the top, but you really can't understand how well Tom has woven in enough personality, so you can truly enjoy reading about this incredibly rigid material. He dissects the Risk Management Framework in a way that facilitates easy digestion and retainment of the material. As an Adjunct Professor of Cybersecurity curriculum, I would absolutely adopt this as required text for several of my courses. Seriously, Tom "break[s] down the framework into easy-to-understand topics..." He doesn't, "go into every detail, or provide every possible way you could implement the framework..." So it gets to the weeds, just not deep in them. I don't know if this will go live with graphics, attachments, or templates (not that it needs them) but there are no images currently in the text (just for those visual learners). But I assure you, Tom nailed it. The right info with just enough detail." https://lnkd.in/eJxu_da6

The introduction of the Healthcare Cybersecurity Act (S. 4697) marks a pivotal step towards bolstering the cybersecurity defenses of healthcare entities. Following the February breach of Change Healthcare, which exposed millions of medical records and disrupted nationwide reimbursements, this bipartisan initiative highlights the urgent need for stronger protections. I see this as a necessary step to ensure not only patient data safety but also to earn back patient loyalty – this will require serious time and effort. For too long companies have been pushing the envelope on integrating tech, without the balancing act of assessing risk. By fostering collaboration between HHS and CISA, and establishing a dedicated liaison, the bill aims to enhance response times and leverage resources effectively. This legislation is poised to safeguard sensitive patient data, ensuring healthcare providers can maintain operational integrity and improve patient outcomes amidst rising cyber threats. #CyberThreats #Healthcare #PatientData #Cybersecurity

Bill 194, Strengthening Cyber Security and Building Trust in the Public Sector Act. Not far after the introduction of Financial Process Integrity and Disclosure Act by the then Senators Mike Oxley (a republican), and Paul Sabarnes (a Democrat), SOX became the go-to for audit control, and financial integrity validations. The two most important of this Act were sections 302 and 404. SOX did not only help traded or listed organizations, but also provided jobs to many in form of consulting, and Subject Matter expertise. Canada would later introduced C-SOX (Bill 198) as a "younger brother" of SOX. Now a new dawn has arrived in Ontario. Welcome Bill 194! Ontario weighs into the responsible use of AI and protection of information within the custody of public entities and municipalities. Ontario is taking steps to ensure a responsible use of AI in public entities, and the disclosure of attacks, breaches and data leaks by the Heads of Agencies and organizations. Bill 194, Strengthening Cyber Security and Building Trust in the Public Sector Act, 2024 is, perhaps the most recent update to the federal PIPEDA. This is definitely not a bad bill from the accounts of ensuring reaponsibilities by the relevant stakeholders. More to come...

On June 18, 2024, the SEC charged R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company (RRD) for failing to maintain adequate internal accounting controls and disclosure controls. These charges violate Section 13(b)(2)(B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. RRD settled with a $2.125M civil penalty due to inadequate policies that led to a ransomware attack, resulting in data encryption, data exfiltration, and business disruptions. Two SEC Commissioners dissented about the SEC's approach. This action is the second time the SEC has used Section 13(b)(2)(B) to fault a company after a cyberattack. The first action against SolarWinds Corporation is under litigation in the Southern District of New York. The SEC's broad interpretation of its jurisdiction is being challenged. Two Commissioners criticized the SEC’s use of Section 13(b)(2)(B) to enforce cybersecurity policies. They argue that the SEC is overreaching by using unrelated statutes to mandate cybersecurity controls. The criticisms are like those against the FTC's use of Section 5 of the FTC Act to require cybersecurity measures not explicitly covered by the statute. The SEC's actions have significant ramifications for companies dealing with cybersecurity breaches. The broad interpretation suggests that companies' information systems are assets, and unauthorized access could lead to SEC violations. This interpretation may regulate public companies' cybersecurity practices. The dissenters argue that internal accounting controls should not extend to broader administrative controls. The SolarWinds case challenges the SEC's interpretation of its jurisdiction under Section 13(b)(2)(B). The outcome may influence whether the SEC can penalize companies victimized by cybercrime. #cybersecurity #SEC #regulation

Inversion technique, risk and shepherding business outcomes with eyes wide open. Earlier this month, I had a conversation with the CTO of a large organization (100,000+ employees), who shared something that left me scratching my head.... When I proposed the idea of security / risk teams being involved early on to provide input into business decisions, the CTO quickly responded with "We make decisions based on prioritizing business outcomes, n͟o͟t͟ what the security / risk teams want us to do". While I agree that business outcomes ought to be maximized on the surface, the CTO's framing insinuated that security and risk were mutually exclusive from business outcomes—this is the part that made me uneasy. As I was thinking about how to reconcile these thoughts, I recently learned of the 𝘪𝘯𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘴𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘩𝘯𝘪𝘲𝘶𝘦, a counterintuitive problem-solving approach practiced by many successful leaders, most notably Charlie Munger. Instead of just focusing on how to achieve success (positive business outcomes), the inversion technique involves considering how to avoid failures (negative business outcomes). Some key 𝘣𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘧𝘪𝘵𝘴 of the inversion technique: - overcome cognitive biases - minimize surprises / disruptions (risk!) - improve decision-making - increase resilience Notice how using the inversion technique likely will drive the implementation of security controls, but the framing is one of business outcomes (not security... or compliance). We discuss the critical need for CISOs to gain robust support from their boards to tackle the growing complexities of managing civil liabilities and regulatory demands effectively. Furthermore, we explore innovative tools like Hyperproof, which are essential for organizations aiming to elevate their cybersecurity maturity amid escalating regulatory pressures. The episode also highlights the dual use of AI in cybersecurity—its potential to streamline and optimize compliance processes while also presenting new challenges that require careful navigation and human oversight. Join us as we provide practical strategies for CISOs and cybersecurity professionals navigating this challenging regulatory and technical environment. #cybersecurity #podcast #GRC
